description: Erection of front porch and rear dormer roof extension with 3 no. front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion
decision_conditions: The erection of a front porch and rear dormer roof extension with 3 no. front rooflights to facilitate a loft conversion falls within the parameters of permitted development as set out under Schedule 2, Part 1, Classes B, C and D of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalThe application seeks planning permission for a single storey side extension that would connect to an existing single storey rear extension. The application proposes materials to match the existing property. Consultation12 Neighbours Notified - no representations received AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of and buildings.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development, whilst not strictly adhering to the guidance in the SPD, would nonetheless, given the existing extensions and alterations to the property, appear subordinate to the existing dwelling and would not adversely effect the character of the wider area.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not have an unacceptable adverse impact upon the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance/loss of light/loss of privacyIt is noted that access to a garage and linked storage for cycling would be removed as a result of the development, as such a condition has been imposed requiring cycle storage to be delivered. It is further noted that sufficient space would be retained for the parking of a motor vehicle. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in general accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The submitted roof plans are not labelled as existing or proposed, please show a North point and a scale.Note: Please provide existing and proposed roof plans at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing the outline of entire property not just part and showing dimensions of proposed work. The plans must show the direction of North. Although the inclusion of a scale bar is not mandatory, it is highly encouraged.
